title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". It includes findings related to the Act. The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of access to credit spread globally, leading the Federal Reserve to establish a target range of 0% to 0.25% in response to the crisis. The Federal Reserve acknowledged the severity of the situation by acting under "unusual and exigent circumstances". The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by acknowledging its severity and exercising its authority to address "unusual and exigent circumstances". This included providing liquidity, stability, and assistance to nonmember institutions, as well as purchasing debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises. The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by purchasing debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises for the first time since 1981. Additionally, joint programs were established with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, including guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America. Chairman Ben Bernanke emphasized transparency in the Federal Reserve's lending programs and balance sheet during a testimony to the Committee on Financial Services. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank, including onsite examinations when deemed necessary. This includes actions approved by the Board under the Federal Reserve Act as the lender of last resort or providing temporary assistance to private institutions. The Federal Reserve Act authorizes the Board of Governors to act as the lender of last resort or provide temporary assistance to private institutions. Various credit facilities fall under this provision, including the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, and others like Maiden Lane, LLC. The Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane, LLC, Maiden Lane II, LLC, Maiden Lane III, LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, Reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles conducting lending activities will cease after a 5-year period. A report on each review conducted must be submitted to Congress by the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of completing each review, detailing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative or administrative action. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. Amends Section 714(d)(1) and Section 714(d)(2) of title 31, United States Code, granting the Comptroller General access to records of agencies and credit facilities, and allowing the retention of copies of such records.
